US https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/flagUSA.jpg Currency: Dollar The United States has a long history with gas masks dating back to the mid 1800's. American were essential inventing many of the earyl gas mask essentials. An early example is the gas mask was patented in 1849, Lewis Haslett. It was an "Inhaler or Lung Protector," issued for an air purifying respirator. Haslett's device filtered dust from the air. When the United States entered the World War I the U.S. Army was unprepared for chemical warfare and had to use borrowed foreign equipment. Soldiers were issued a British Small Box Respirator for the highest level of protection and a French M2 Mask for long-term wear comfort. Unfortunately, the untrained troops had a tendency to initially put on the S.B.R. following a gas attack and then switch to the M2 when it appeared they would have to wear a mask for an extended period of time. Of course, during the mask switching, many soldiers inhaled toxic chemicals and became casualties. From then On the Military Issued its own masks. Later Innovations Followed

American Small Box Respirator (A.S.B.R.) American Small Box Respirator (A.S.B.R.)
The Training Mask c. 1917 Rare/Scarce United States Military US-001 US-001 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-001.jpg $325 The American Small Box Respirator (A.S.B.R.) was a hastily developed mask loosely based on the British Small Box Respirator. It used a similar carrier, filter and head harness. The mask's face piece was also designed so the wearer could wipe the eye pieces clean with a finger from the outside of the mask, again copying the British mask. But, soon after the A.S.B.R. went into production, it was found to have many shortcomings, particularly within the filter unit. So, the A.S.B.R. was quickly replaced by the Corrected English Model (see below). Remaining A.S.B.R.s had the top of the filter canister painted red, and the mask was then only used for drills and training exercises. Thus, it became known as the Training Mask. The A.S.B.R. is easily identified by the presence of the tall black and red filter canister and the lack of any type of exhale valve guard. While over 25,000 A.S.B.R.s were produced, the mask remains to be one of the more difficult US W.W.I masks to find today.

Corrected English Model (C.E.M.) Corrected English Model (C.E.M.)
C.E. Mask (Corrected English Mask) c. 1917/1918 Common United States Military US-002 US-002 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-002.jpg $190 Perhaps the most commonly found of the US W.W.I masks is the Corrected English Model (C.E.M.). After the failure of the American Small Box Respirator, the C.E.M. was developed in an attempt to fix many of the problems with earlier box respirator designs. Several different developments were made over the years while the C.E.M. was in production, and before the end of W.W.I, nearly 2 million C.E.M. masks were produced. Because of the rapid pace of research at the time, several different variants of the C.E.M. were manufactured. The most common versions came with a yellow 'H' filter canister and a thin metal exhale valve guard. However, later versions of the mask used the improved 'J' type filter which was painted green. In addition, some later variants used a wider metal exhale valve guard to better protect the fragile, 'flapper' type exhale valve.

Corrected English Model (C.E.M.) Corrected English Model (C.E.M.)
C.E. Mask (Corrected English Mask) c. 1917/1918 Common United States Military US-177 US-177 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-177.jpg $125 This version of the C.E.M. used celluloid eye pieces and had no exhale valve guard. This version clearly illustrates how many different modifications were made to this early design. It is also possible that this is an early version, made before any versions with exhale valve guards were introduced.

Corrected English Model (C.E.M.) Corrected English Model (C.E.M.)
C.E. Mask (Corrected English Mask) c. 1917/1918 Rare (size 5) United States Military US-003 US-003 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-003.jpg $285 The C.E.M. mask was manufactured in five different sizes to accommodate different head and face shapes. Most C.E.M. masks have the size number stamped on the front of the mask and on the outside of the mask's carrier. Some masks were made in an extra wide size, and are typically marked as such (i.e. 4 WIDE) At right, a size 5 (the largest size) is pictured. The size 5 seems to be quite uncommon, while size 3 masks seem to be the most significantly produced.

Corrected English Model (C.E.M.) Corrected English Model (C.E.M.)
C.E. Mask (Corrected English Mask) c. 1917/1918 Rare (with black and yellow filter) United States Military US-004 US-004 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-004.jpg $190 A rare variant of the C.E.M. was also assembled with a black and yellow painted filter canister. This is perhaps a specialized filter for certain hazards (like ammonia or carbon monoxide) or also maybe a faulty 'H' filter that was only used for training.

Corrected English Model (C.E.M.) Corrected English Model (C.E.M.)
n/a c. 1917/1918 Common United States Military US-005 US-005 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-005.jpg $105 A later version of the C.E.M. Featured a green type 'J' filter canister and a different exhale valve guard made from wider pieces of metal. This most likely helped protect the rubber 'flapper type' exhale valve from getting torn off in the field. It might also be noted that the C.E.M. was manufactured with both glass eye pieces and celluloid eye pieces (glass however, seems to be more common). Also, most C.E.M. masks are usually stamped 'C.E.' on the chin just behind the exhale valve, making them easily identifiable. The C.E.M. can still be found in excellent condition with the flutter valve intact, but masks in this shape usually bring high prices on the collectors market.

Corrected English Model (C.E.M.) Corrected English Model (C.E.M.)
n/a c. 1917/1918 Rare United States Military US-175 US-175 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-175.jpg $145 This version of the C.E.M. had a red painted filter. It is unknown if this is a post war modification or if the filter was painted red for some other reason (training, faulty, etc.). Either way, yet another interesting variant of the C.E.M. design.

Richardson, Flory & Kops (R.F.K.) Gas Mask Richardson, Flory & Kops (R.F.K.) Gas Mask
n/a c. 1918 Uncommon United States Military US-006 US-006 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-006.jpg $145 The R.F.K. mask, named after three members of the Chemical Warfare Service (Ralph Richardson, E.L. Flory and Waldemar Kops), looks identical to the C.E.M. at a glance. However, there are quite a few differences. Mainly, the mask used a different head harness, consisting of two straps on either side of the forehead, as opposed to just one in the center as with the Corrected English Model. The R.F.K.'s face piece was also shaped a little differently than the C.E.M., giving it a wider appearance when worn. While more R.F.K. masks were produced during the war period, they seem to be somewhat more difficult to find, especially in good condition. The mask pictured at right still has the flapper type exhale valve intact, although completely hardened.

Connel Gas Mask Connel Gas Mask
Connell Gas Mask c. 1919 Very Scarce USA Military US-007 US-007 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-007.jpg ? $100+ The US Connel Gas Mask is an experimental gas mask made by the British for use by the US Chemical Warfare Service. The face piece was made of a combination of metal and canvas with an early foam rubber material used to create a face seal. The filter canister was suspended behind the wearers head and was connected to a single corrugated rubber tube that attached to an inlet on the left side of the face piece. Inside the mask, air was directed over the circular glass eye pieces to aid demisting. Exhaled air was pushed out through a rubber exhale valve (missing in photo) fitted to an opening on the front of the mask. It is unknown how many Connel masks were procured by the US, but it is unquestionably an extremely rare gas mask to find today.

Akron-Tissot (A.T.) Gas Mask Akron-Tissot (A.T.) Gas Mask
n/a c. 1918 Scarce United States Military US-008 US-008 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-008.jpg ? $75+ The A.T. Mask was made by the Akron Rubber Company (Akron, Ohio), and used the French Tissot principle. This being the idea of directing inhaled air over the eye pieces to keep them from fogging, a common problem with most early gas masks. There were at least two different variants of the A.T. Mask produced. One had olive painted eye piece frames (pictured at right) while another version had crimped black metal frames. The A.T. mask usually bears a red stamp on the side of the face piece indicating 'AT'. Due to the nature of the materials used to manufacture this mask, few remain today. When found, the A.T. Mask is usually in completely hardened condition.

Kops-Tissot (K.T.) Gas Mask Kops-Tissot (K.T.) Gas Mask
n/a c. 1918 Scarce United States Military US-009 US-009 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-009.jpg ? $100+ The K.T. Mask was another WWI mask that used the Tissot principle, and was developed by Waldemar Kops, a regular name in early respirator design. The K.T. was produced in at least two versions. The early version featured threaded eye piece frames and a yellow 'H' type filter canister. The later version (at right) featured pressed eye piece frames and a green 'J' type filter canister. Like the A.T. Mask, the K.T. Mask is also very scarce today, and when found is typically in poor condition.

US Navy Gas Mask, Mark I (Mouth Canister Type) US Navy Gas Mask, Mark I (Mouth Canister Type)
n/a c. 1917 Scarce United States Military US-135 US-135 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-135.jpg $325 This early Navy development was designed to combine the best elements of the German Gummischutzmaske and the British Small Box Respirator. This allowed for a high level of protection and comfort while allowing for a greater level of mobility (compared to other US gas masks in use at the time). Like the German Gummischutzmaske, the Navy Mark I was also issued in a similar metal carrying canister. However unlike the German Gummischutzmaske, the MK. I used a wide rubber flapper type exhale valve that protruded from the filter inlet stem. Like the C.E.M., The Navy Mouth Canister mask used nose clips and a snorkel like mouth piece on the inside. There were two versions of the Mouth Canister mask developed, one with filter support straps on the outside (at right) and one with the support straps on the inside (below). The Navy MK. I can still be found today on the collector's market in fair to good condition, but it is quite rare and usually expensive to obtain.

US Navy Gas Mask, Mark I (Mouth Canister Type) US Navy Gas Mask, Mark I (Mouth Canister Type)
n/a c. 1917 Rare/Scarce United States Military US-010 US-010 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-010.jpg $325 This version of the Navy Mark I was most likely designed after the above version. While both versions are very similar, this example was manufactured with the filter support straps on the inside of the mask. In addition, wider head harness straps were also used, probably making the mask more durable overall. This version of the Mouth Canister Gas Mask seems to be more common than the above version.

US Navy Gas Mask, Mark II (Head Canister Type) US Navy Gas Mask, Mark II (Head Canister Type)
n/a c. 1919 Scarce United States Navy US-011 US-011 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-011.jpg $150 Of all the US developments during these early years, the Navy MK. II Head Canister Gas Mask is certainly the most peculiar. The filter canister was worn on top of the head as part of an integrated helmet-like, metal support system. Air was inhaled through an opening in the back of the filter canister and drawn through to the front of the canister and down into the mask via two short rubber hoses that connected just above the eye pieces. Exhaled air was directed up and out through a flapper type exhale valve located on the forehead of the mask. The mask was also issued with two rectangular 'filter pads' that were connected to a metal assembly that could be attached to the filter canister in the rear. These pads were used to capture smoke and other particles. The WWI US Navy Mark II is quite rare, and when found, is usually in very poor condition.

Kops, Tissot, Monro (K.T.M.) Gas Mask Kops, Tissot, Monro (K.T.M.) Gas Mask
Model 1919 Gas Mask, MI Service Gas Mask c. 1919 Rare/Scarce United States Military US-012 US-012 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-012.jpg $325 After much trial and error during W.W.I, Waldemar Kops and Randolph Monro developed a new mask that once again used the Tissot principle for demisting. It was initially called the K.T.M. mask, but soon came to be known as the Model 1919. The mask's face piece was made from a special sheet of stockinet covered rubber, which was sewn together at the chin to create a proper face form. This gave the mask a higher level of protection and a better fit than any previous designs. In the years to follow leading up to the start of W.W.II, the K.T.M. went through many significant changes, particularly with the filter. Early versions of the mask used a blue painted box type filter canister that was continually modified until the standardization of the MIXA1 heavy- weight canister. The K.T.M. was finally standardized as the Army MI Service Gas Mask in 1921 after several changes to the filter, hose tube and carrier.

Kops, Tissot, Monro (K.T.M.) Gas Mask Kops, Tissot, Monro (K.T.M.) Gas Mask
Model 1919 Gas Mask, MI Service Gas Mask c. 1919 Rare/Scarce United States Military US-013 US-013 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-013.jpg $325 This version of the K.T.M. is more or less identical to the above, original version. However, this version is fitted with a Type G Training Filter. Both versions of this mask are quite difficult to find today, particularly with an intact flapper type exhale valve, which is missing entirely from the specimen pictured to the right.

US Army MI Service Gas Mask US Army MI Service Gas Mask
Model 1919 c. 1930s Scarce United States Military US-127 US-127 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-127.jpg $200 The MI Service gas mask was basically an upgraded version of the early K.T.M. Gas Mask (see above). It was what would eventually become the MIA1 Service Gas Mask and subsequently the widely produced MIA2 Service Gas Mask. At a glance, the MI appears to be identical to the MIA1 or MIA2, however this earlier version had several different features. Most notably, the eye piece frames were crimped instead of threaded. Also the filter canister used was of the early MV III type. The mask pictured to the right is very early, and used an older spring type head harness. The outside of face piece bears no size stamps or any other markings of any kind. Intact MI Service Masks are very difficult to find today, and when located are typically in deteriorated condition with hardened or missing 'flapper type' exhale valves.

US Army MIA1 Service Gas Mask US Army MIA1 Service Gas Mask
n/a c. 1920s Rare United States Navy US-014 US-014 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-014.jpg $200 The Army MIA1 Service Gas Mask served as an upgrade to the US MI Service Gas Mask. It used threaded eye piece frames, a slightly different face blank and a new MII head harness. The MIA1 also introduced a new filter canister that offered less breathing resistance and better filtering properties. The MIA1 was manufactured in 4 sizes, but was later replaced by the MIA2 which was made in one universal size (see below). The MIA1 is somewhat scarce today, but can still be found in mint, un-issued co nditio n.

US Army MIA2 Service Gas Mask US Army MIA2 Service Gas Mask
n/a c. 1930s Rare United States Military US-015 US-015 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-015.jpg $130 The Army MIA2 Service Gas Mask is more or less identical to the MIA1 (above). However, the MIA2 was manufactured in one universal size, as opposed to 4 different sizes like the MIA1. The head harness was also sewn onto the face piece in a slightly different arrangement, probably to enhance comfort and fit. The face piece of the MIA2 is generally bigger and has a longer forehead; this again is most likely to accommodate the most common head sizes. The MIA2 was originally manufactured with a khaki stockinet face piece and was later issued with a gray stockinet face piece and a greenish-gray rubber hose (below). Both versions are becoming more and more difficult to locate on the collector's market.

US Army MIA2 Service Gas Mask US Army MIA2 Service Gas Mask
n/a c. 1930s Rare United States Military US-016 US-016 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-016.jpg $170 This version of the Army MIA2 Service Gas Mask is basically identical to the above version, but was manufactured with a gray colored stockinet face piece, a gray rubber exhale valve and a gray rubber hose tube. Both versions seem to be about equally as difficult to find today.

US Army/Navy MI Diaphragm Gas Mask US Army/Navy MI Diaphragm Gas Mask
n/a c. 1920s Scarce United States Military US-139 US-139 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-139.jpg $450 A modification of the MI face piece to fit a speech diaphragm resulted in the Mark I Diaphragm Gas Mask. This mask, designed by Randolph Monro, was used by both the Army and the Navy, and came in four different sizes. A large speech diaphragm was located on the front of the mask with a flutter type exhale valve and breathing tube connector just below. On the inside, dual metal pipes directed inhaled air over the eye pieces, applying the Tissot principle. The mask was slung in a standard 'kidney' shaped, khaki carrier. Future modifications to the Mark I resulted in the MIA1 Diaphragm Gas Mask and later the MII Diaphragm Gas Mask (see below). Also, a civilian version of this mask was made for use by miners and fireman (see US-107).

US Army/Navy MIA1 Diaphragm Gas Mask US Army/Navy MIA1 Diaphragm Gas Mask
n/a c. 1920s Scarce United States Military US-017 US-017 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-017.jpg SOLD The MIA1 Diaphragm Gas Mask is simply an updated version of the MI Diaphragm Gas Mask (see above). When the Army introduced the MIA1 Service Gas Mask (US-014), the Diaphragm gas mask was also updated. The crimped eye piece frames were replaced with threaded frames and the head harness was also updated. A few other slight changes were also incorporated, but the overall appearance of the Diaphragm gas mask stayed the same.

US Army/Navy MII Diaphragm Gas Mask US Army/Navy MII Diaphragm Gas Mask
n/a c. 1930s Scarce United States Military US-018 US-018 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-018.jpg $450 Further modifications to the diaphragm mask resulted in the MII Diaphragm Gas Mask. The MII used a peculiar setup with the speech diaphragm located on the front behind the flutter type exhale valve, which was pointed upward. Inhaled air was separated into two metal tubes that directed air flow over the eye pieces to help reduce fogging. These Tissot tubes are clearly visible through the glass eye pieces. The mask's face piece was manufactured in one universal size, making production faster and more cost effective. Today, both Mark I and Mark II Diaphragm Gas Masks are quite rare, making them highly collectable early US respirato rs.

US Army/Navy MII Diaphragm Gas Mask US Army/Navy MII Diaphragm Gas Mask
n/a c. 1930s Scarce United States Military US-019 US-019 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-019.jpg ? $200+ This version of the Mark II Diaphragm Gas Mask is basically identical to the above version, but varies slightly. Firstly, the mask pictured to the right used an old style, spring type head harness (see details). In addition, this mask was made with black rubber as opposed to tan rubber used with the above version. The angle tube used to connect the filter canister is also smaller and shorter than the above version. Both variants are quite rare, and when found are often in very poor condition.

US Army M2 Training Gas Mask US Army M2 Training Gas Mask
MI Training Mask (early nomenclature) c. 1939 Scarce United States Military/Civilian US-020 US-020 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-020.jpg ? $200+ The first US gas mask to use a fully molded rubber face piece was the MI Training Gas Mask. The face blank, later designated the M2 face piece, went on to be the basis for most WWII US gas masks to follow. The Training Mask was equipped with a long filter canister, also designated the MI, attached directly to the bottom of the mask. Pictured to the right is the first model of the Training mask which had the MIV "Acushnet" type exhale valve instead of the later more widely used MV "Connel" type exhale valve. The MI also did not have rifle skids, as did later versions. This early version is quite scarce, as it was not made in significant enough numbers before it was replaced by the MIA1.

US Army M2A1 Training Gas Mask US Army M2A1 Training Gas Mask
MIA1 Training Mask (early nomenclature) c. 1939 Rare/Scarce United States Military/Civilian US-021 US-021 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-021.jpg $360 Soon after the MI Training Gas Mask went into production, it was updated and renamed the MIA1 Training Gas Mask. This version of the Training mask used a new face piece mold which included "rifle skids", a feature designed to prevent the wearer's rifle from getting caught on the lower head harness rivets when aiming from the shoulder position. The MIA1 also did away with the early MIV "Acushnet" type exhale valve, replacing it with an updated MV "Connel" style valve. Early MIA1s were made of all black rubber, like the MI, but were later made from the more common greenish-gray rubber.

US Army M2A1 Training Gas Mask US Army M2A1 Training Gas Mask
MIA1 Training Mask (early nomenclature) c. 1939 Rare/Scarce United States Military/Civilian US-022 US-022 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-022.jpg $340 The MIA1 mask pictured to the right is more or less the same as the version above, however this one was manufactured by Firestone, giving it a slightly different appearance from the Acushnet versions pictured above. There were several different companies making gas masks for the US Army at the time, and early on there were slightly different molds being used at varying factories. In some cases, this posed a problem for manufactures constructing standard hardware, head harnesses and filter units for the early masks. Many issues such as this came about during the early years of gas mask experimentation, thus keeping gas mask evolution on the move.

US Army M2A1 Training Gas Mask US Army M2A1 Training Gas Mask
MIA1 Training Mask (early nomenclature) c. 1939 Uncommon/Rare United States Military/Civilian US-023 US-023 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-023.jpg $105 This example of the MIA1 was also made by Firestone, but it was molded from greenish-gray colored rubber. The filter unit was also painted gray instead of olive green. This version of the Training Mask was manufactured in large quantities, and was used extensively by military personnel and civilians alike stationed on islands in the Pacific. Around this time, the US Chemical Warfare Service also redesigned their nomenclature system, getting away entirely from using Roman numerals. The designation for the Training Mask was changed to M2 (and M2A1 respectively).

US Army M2A1 Training Gas Mask US Army M2A1 Training Gas Mask
US Army M2A2 Training Gas Mask c. 1940s Rare United States Military/Civilian US-024 US-024 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-024.jpg $290 This version of the Training Mask, also designated the M2A1, used a M8 type exhale valve. It is possible that this version was made from M2A2 Service Gas Masks. However it is possible that these were manufactured from the start as Training Gas Masks, but with updated M8 exhale valves. These later versions do not seem to be as common as the previous version with the MV exhale valve.

US Army M2A1 Service Gas Mask US Army M2A1 Service Gas Mask
n/a c. 1939/1940 Rare United States Military US-025 US-025 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-025.jpg $175 The M2A1 Service Gas Mask used the same face piece and exhale valve setup as the M2A1 Training Gas Mask (above). However, a long rubber breathing tube with a MIXA1 filter canister attached was used instead of the MI training filter. The M2A1 Service Gas Mask is not quite as common as the later service masks making it somewhat difficult to find on the collector's market.

US Army M2A2 Service Gas Mask US Army M2A2 Service Gas Mask
n/a c. 1939/1940 Uncommon/Rare United States Military US-026 US-026 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-026.jpg $165 A modification of the the exhale valve of the M2A1 Service Gas Mask resulted in the M2A2 Service Gas Mask. The masks are identical otherwise. This mask is what would ultimately be the basis for the later M3 and M4 series service masks. The main problem with the M2 series service was the lack of in internal nose cup to reduce fogging and the heavyweight filter canister. Both of these issues were addressed with the introduction of the M3 and M4 series Lightweight Service Gas Masks. The M2A2 was manufactured in large numbers and can still be frequently found today in very good condition.

US Army M2A2 Service Gas Mask US Army M2A2 Service Gas Mask
n/a c. 1941 Rare/Scarce United States Military US-205 US-205 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-205.jpg $250 This variant of the M2A2 was manufactured by Goodyear and is basically the same as the above mask. This one however used a gray MIVA1 filter canister, which may be experimental. The mask's face piece appears to be an early type of black rubber, but not neoprene. This rare mask is most likely an experimental or prototype design made during the early years of WWII.

US Army M2A2 Special Oil Vapor Gas Mask US Army M2A2 Special Oil Vapor Gas Mask
n/a c. 1940s Scarce United States Military US-027 US-027 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-027.jpg $250 Sometime during the 1940s, the US Army manufactured several "Standardized Special Gas Masks". Among these special gas masks were the M2A2 Acid Vapor Gas Mask, the M2A2 Ammonia Gas Mask, the M2A2 HCN Gas Mask and the M2A2 Oil Vapor Gas Mask (at right). Each came equipped with a specially labeled filter canister designed to protect against a specific gas. For all practical purposes the mask was identical to the M2A2 Service Gas Mask, but had no rifle skids and a slightly different head harness assembly (identical to the M3 series). This is certainly one of the best examples of how confusing early US nomenclature can be. These special gas masks are quite scarce today as few were manufactured, obviously due to a small demand.

US Army M3-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask US Army M3-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask
n/a c. 1944 Uncommon/Rare United States Military US-028 US-028 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-028.jpg $140 The Army M3-10A1-6 was a modification of the earlier M2A2 Service Gas Mask. The mask was designed to be lighter, so a shorter breathing tube was used with a lightweight M10A1 filter canister fixed to the end. An inner oronasal cup was also incorporated to reduce fogging of the eye pieces. The head harness was also riveted onto the face piece differently, so as to not require rifle skids. This factor makes the M3-10A1-6 easy to distinguish from the other lightweight service gas masks. The M3-10A1-6 was made in fairly significant numbers but it is still somewhat difficult to find today.

US Army M3-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask US Army M3-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask
n/a c. 1944 Uncommon/Rare United States Military US-029 US-029 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-029.jpg $145 More commonly found is the black neoprene rubber M3-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask. Because of natural rubber shortages, an alternative synthetic rubber was in need, and thus Neoprene was used. While Neoprene met most of the demands required to construct a protective mask, the synthetic rubber was found to have a problem when exposed to colder weather. The face piece would get stiff and difficult to don, a condition known as "cold-set". This problem led to the eventual elimination of Neoprene rubber gas masks. However, it is the M3-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask which was converted post production into the the well known M5-11-7 Assault Gas Mask.

US Army M3-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask (L - Large Sized Version) US Army M3-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask (L - Large Sized Version)
n/a c. 1944 Scarce United States Military US-030 US-030 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-030.jpg $220 The version of the M3-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask pictured to the right is a rare size large mask. The standard was to produce service masks in one universal size (marked with a large letter 'U' on the forehead). There was however a need to accommodate a smaller number of otherwise abnormally large or small head sizes, thus small numbers of these large sized masks were produced with a large letter 'L' on the forehead. It should also be noted that a 'SS' or 'Super Small' version of some service masks were produced during the late war years as well (see below).

US Army M3A1-10A1-6 Lightweight Gas Mask US Army M3A1-10A1-6 Lightweight Gas Mask
n/a c. 1944 Uncommon/Rare United States Military US-031 US-031 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-031.jpg $110 The Army M3A1-10A1-6 is identical to the M3-10A1-6 but used a C15 exhale valve as opposed to the more common M8 exhale valve. The same carrier, filter, inner oronasal cup and face blank was used. For some reason the M3A1 seems to be slightly more common than the earlier M3, but for the most part these masks are becoming harder to find.

US Army M4-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask US Army M4-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask
n/a c. 1944 Uncommon United States Military US-032 US-032 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-032.jpg $125 Another modification to the M2A2 Service Gas Mask yielded the M4-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask. These masks were typically made with an olive drab rubber face piece and breathing tube, but occasionally Neoprene breathing tubes were fitted. It must also be noted that these masks are commonly found with different colors of paint, elastic and plastic dye, as several different manufacturers were constructing the masks towards the end of the war. Notice the rifle skid moldings and the same head harness rivet placement as the M2A2. The only difference between the M4 and the later M4A1 was that the M4 used a M8 exhale valve and the M4A1 used a C15 exhale valve. Both the M4 and M4A1 seem to be much more common than the M3 series lightweight service gas masks.

US Army M4-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask US Army M4-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask
n/a c. 1944 Uncommon United States Military US-033 US-033 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-033.jpg $100 This M4-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask is pictured to demonstrate the variation in colors commonly found with these masks. The example pictured to the right was made by Firestone Tire & Rubber Company, whereas the above example is was made by General Tire & Rubber Company. It must also be noted that some M4s lack an inner nose cup, possibly due to rubber shortages.

US Army M4-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask (SS - Super Small Version) US Army M4-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask (SS - Super Small Version)
n/a c . 1944 Uncommon/Rare United States Military US-034 US-034 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-034.jpg $85 Another interesting variation of the M4-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask is the 'SS' version (super small version). Typically, the M4 was issued in one universal face piece size (marked with a large letter 'U' on the forehead) making the super small version (marked with the letters 'SS' on the forehead) somewhat rare. There are several other notable differences as well. Because of the smaller size, the mask was not manufactured with an inner oronasal nose cup, and the head harness pad was also left out. These differences, could only be due to the smaller face piece assembly.

US Army M4A1-10A1-6 Lightweight Gas Mask US Army M4A1-10A1-6 Lightweight Gas Mask
n/a c. 1944 Uncommon United States Military US-035 US-035 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-035.jpg $110 A few slight modifications to the M4-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask yielded the M4A1-10A1-6 Lightweight Service Gas Mask. These masks were typically made with an olive drab rubber face piece and breathing tube, but occasionally Neoprene breathing tubes were fitted. Notice the rifle skid moldings and the same head harness rivet placement as the M4. The main difference between the M4 and the M4A1 was the exhale valve.

US Army M5-11-7 Assault Gas Mask US Army M5-11-7 Assault Gas Mask
Combat Service Gas Mask, Invasion Gas Mask c. 1944 Uncommon United States Military US-036 US-036 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-036.jpg $175 The US Army Assault Gas Mask is quite possibly the most sought after WWII US gas mask due to the fact that it is this mask that was carried during the D-day Invasion of Normandy. The M5-11-7 was originally inspired by the British MK. I Light Anti-Gas Respirator and was intended to be a light weight mask that soldiers could carry during amphibious assaults. Thus, the mask was issued with a carrier made of a waterproof rubberized duck material which doubled as a floatation device when in use. The M5-11-7 was quickly phased out when it was discovered that the neoprene face piece was subject to a hardening known as "cold-set". While the M5-11-7 always brings a high price on the surplus/collector's market, it is still quite common and can be found in mint, un-issued condition.

US Army M8 Snout-Type Gas Mask US Army M8 Snout-Type Gas Mask
n/a c. 1944 Rare United States Military US-037 US-037 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-037.jpg $185 The Army M8 Snout Type gas mask is quite interesting in that is was constructed from un-issued M4A1 Lightweight Service Gas Masks as a quick replacement for the M5 Assault Gas Mask after it was found to have problems with "cold-set". A 60mm filter inlet was mounted to the chin of the face piece to allow the use of the standard M11 drum type canister. Because this mask was needed toward the end of WWII, few were manufactured Thus, it is somewhat difficult to find today.

US Army M3 Diaphragm Gas Mask (1941 Mfg.) US Army M3 Diaphragm Gas Mask (1941 Mfg.)
n/a c. 1940 Uncommon United States Military/Civilian US-038 US-038 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-038.jpg $115 In order to accommodate the necessity for a gas mask with an able speech diaphragm, the M3 Diaphragm Gas Mask was introduced. The front of the face piece was fitted with a metal speech diaphragm assembly which was situated just above a flutter type exhale valve. This configuration meant that the breathing tube could not be connected directly to the face piece. Instead, a hard plastic tube was fitted into two holes on either side of the face piece with the breathing tube connected to the center of the tube (angled slightly forward). The M3 Diaphragm mask was manufactured in significant numbers, and is thus not difficult to locate on the collector's market, however this early version with black metal parts and black head harness seems to be more scarce.

US Army M3 Diaphragm Gas Mask (1943 Mfg.) US Army M3 Diaphragm Gas Mask (1943 Mfg.)
n/a c. 1940 Uncommon United States Military/Civilian US-039 US-039 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-039.jpg $115 This M3 Diaphragm Gas Mask is identical to the above mask in design, but has olive-drab painted metal parts and a matching head harness. This variation in color may simply be a result of different manufacturers, although there may be a functional purpose to color changes. The all green version pictured to the right seems to be the most commonly found on the collector's market.

US Army M3A1 Diaphragm Gas Mask US Army M3A1 Diaphragm Gas Mask
n/a c. 1942 Common/Uncommon United States
Military US-040 US-040 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-040.jpg $95 A modification to the speech diaphragm and exhale valve assembly of the M3 Diaphragm Gas Mask lead to the M3A1 Diaphragm Gas Mask. The M3A1 was essentially identical to the M3, but a new plastic voice-mitter/exhale valve assembly was used in place of the earlier metal type. The new parts were most likely functionally superior to the previous types as well as lighter. The M3A1 Diaphragm Gas Mask was manufactured in large numbers, thus is quite common on the collector's market today.

US Army Gas Mask (Reconditioned For Training) US Army Gas Mask (Reconditioned For Training)
n/a c. 1950s Uncommon United States Military US-192 US-192 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-192.jpg ? $75 After WWII, several left-over gas masks were "reconditioned" and used for training purposes. This particular mask, was made from M3A1 Diaphragm parts and equipped with a M10A1 filter canister. The mask's carrier was also altered to reflect that the mask was only to be used for training purposes.

US Army MI-I-5 Optical Gas Mask US Army MI-I-5 Optical Gas Mask
Army Artillery Gas Mask, Army Tank Gas Mask c. 1941 Scarce United States Military US-041 US-041 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-041.jpg $300 During the early stages of gas mask development in 1920s, it was apparent that a gas mask for use with optical sighting devices (like scopes and binoculars) was needed. In 1941, the Army designed and standardized the Army MI-I-5 Optical Gas Mask. It was more or less identical to the Navy version (below) but the two do have some significant differences. The distance between the small round eye pieces could be adjusted via a threaded rod, accommodating a wide range of head sizes. The mask's filter canister was suspended behind the wearer's neck by means of a metal clip on the filter that was attached to a canvas sleeve sewn onto the head harness. Inhaled air was drawn through a horizontal slit in the filter. Today, the Army MI Optical Gas Mask is among the rarest of the WWII US gas masks. While the Army version was not made in significant numbers, the Navy Diaphragm Optical Gas Mask was manufactured and issued in quantity to soldiers aboard ships.

US Army MI-I-5 Optical Gas Mask US Army MI-I-5 Optical Gas Mask
US NDO Mark I Gas Mask c. 1941 Rare United States Military US-042 US-042 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-042.jpg $300 This US optical gas mask is most likely an updated Army version of the above green type. This mask is what would later be molded with the USN face piece and designated the Navy Diaphragm Optical (NDO) Mark I Gas Mask (see below). These early Army version are much more rare than the US Navy versions which were made in more significant numbers.

US Navy Diaphragm Optical (NDO) Mark I Gas Mask US Navy Diaphragm Optical (NDO) Mark I Gas Mask
n/a c. 1941 Uncommon United States Navy US-043 US-043 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-043.jpg $140 For the Navy, a gas masks that could be used with optical sighting devices was in demand during WWII. As a result, a modified version of the Army MI Optical Gas Mask was made for use aboard ships. It was designated the Navy Diaphragm Optical Gas Mask, Mark I. Like the Army version, the distance between the small round eye pieces could be adjusted via a threaded rod, accommodating a wide range of head sizes. The mask's filter canister was suspended behind the wearer's neck with a metal clip, which was attached to the back of the head harness. From a series of small holes along the back of the filter, inhaled air was drawn through two corrugated rubber tubes and forced over the eye pieces to help keep them from fogging. While the N.D.O. Mark I is not as common as the later Navy Diaphragm masks, it is still fairly easy to find on the collector's market.

US Army/Navy Diaphragm Gas Mask US Army/Navy Diaphragm Gas Mask
n/a c. 1938 Rare/Scarce United States Army/Navy US-206 US-206 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-206.jpg $140 This early diaphragm mask was manufactured in 1938, and used the old style filter suspension method (see DETAILS below). This design, is what would eventually become standardized by the Navy, as the ND Mark III (see below). Both this version and the regular Navy version are quite similar, however this version does not bear a USN mold marking on the forehead, and has the older type filter clip on the back. This particular mask may have been used by the Army, or it may simply be an early production ND Mark III.

US Navy Diaphragm (ND) Mark III Gas Mask US Navy Diaphragm (ND) Mark III Gas Mask
n/a c. 1942 Uncommon/Rare United States Navy US-044 US-044 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-044.jpg $125 Following the same design as the earlier N.D.O. Mark I, the ND Mark III was manufactured. This mask was not an optical mask, but did have special elliptically shaped eye pieces designed to enhance peripheral vision. This is the only difference between the Mark I and the Mark III. The filter canister was suspended behind the neck in the same manner as well. This configuration was used to give the soldier's head more freedom while maneuvering in the confines of a ship. The Mark III was manufactured in significant enough numbers to make it somewhat common today, but it was replaced by the Mark IV, which was manufactured towards the end of the war, and in much greater numbers.

US Navy Diaphragm (ND) Mark IV Gas Mask US Navy Diaphragm (ND) Mark IV Gas Mask
n/a c. 1944 Common United States Navy US-045 US-045 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-045.jpg $80 The Navy Diaphragm Mark IV was nothing more than an improved Mark III. It was found that the elliptical eye pieces used on the Mark III where not as efficient as the larger triangular eye pieces used with the Mark IV. This is the only difference between the two masks. The Mark IV is perhaps one of the most commonly found W.W.II Navy masks today. It can still be found in un-issued condition packed inside it's original cardboard box.

US Navy Diaphragm (ND) Mark IV Gas Mask (Modified for shallow water diving) US Navy Diaphragm (ND) Mark IV Gas Mask (Modified for shallow water diving)
Damage-Control Hose Mask c. 1944/1945 Scarce United States Navy US-131 US-131 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-131.jpg ? $300+ In 1944 the Navy published several documents outlining the use of existing ND Mark III and IV gas masks for shallow water diving purposes. These masks were altered aboard ships and stowed in "damage-control" repair lockers. If needed, a diver could don the mask, which was connected to a air supply line, and dive up to depths of 36 feet. The peculiar example pictured to the right appears to fit the description of such modified gas masks almost perfectly. However, the example pictured to the right features an early Western Electric microphone in place of the diaphragm. The microphone connection cord has been cut, which means it could have been quite long (long enough for a 36 foot dive), and would also suggest that the microphone is water-proof as well as air-tight. The filter canister was removed and in place a "T" shaped brass connector was inserted and sealed with cement. These "on-the-fly" modified gas masks are quite scarce today in any condition.

Unknown Unknown
n/a c. 1939 Scarce United States Military US-046 US-046 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-046.jpg ? $100+ The modified Mark III Diaphragm mask pictured to the right was manufactured by Acushnet and is dated 1939. The face piece used the US Army mold, which would make this mask an Army used mask and not a Navy mask, as with the below example. These modified Mark III Diaphragm masks may have been used as special purpose masks connected to a supplied air system, but their true function is not known.

Unknown Unknown
n/a c. 1942 Scarce United States Military US-132 US-132 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-132.jpg $275 The modified Mark III Diaphragm mask pictured to the right was manufactured by MSA and is dated 1942. The face piece used the US Navy mold, which would make this mask an Navy used mask and not an Army mask, as with the above example. These modified Mark III Diaphragm masks may have been used as special purpose masks connected to a supplied air system, but their true function is not known.

US Navy Oxygen Rescue Breathing Apparatus US Navy Oxygen Rescue Breathing Apparatus
Type A-I (NORBA Type A-1) c. 1941 Rare United States Military (Navy) US-047 US-047 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-047.jpg $300 The Navy Oxygen Rescue Breathing Apparatus was made from modified ND Mark III and Mark IV gas mask molds and was housed in a large gray trunk (see DETAILS). The mask was used as a short term oxygen generating rescue apparatus for emergency situations where the oxygen level in the air was too low to sustain life, or other harmful gases were present. When the canister seal was broken, a chemical reaction forced oxygen into a large bladder that was worn around the front of the body. Expired air was breathed back into the canister and recycled back into oxygen for re-breathing. Each canister could be used for 30 to 45 minutes before a fresh canister had to be installed. A starter valve on the front of the mask allowed the wearer to breath outside air while the chemical reaction inflated the breathing bag with oxygen. Once this process was complete, the starter valve could be closed and re-breathing could begin. The N.O.R.B.A. is somewhat rare today, and when found most are in poor and/or incomplete condition.

US Navy Smoke Mask, Model NM US Navy Smoke Mask, Model NM
n/a c. 1941 Rare United States Military (Navy) US-130 US-130 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-130.jpg $290 The Navy Smoke Mask Model NM is very similar to the NORBA Type A-1 (above). The face piece assembly is virtually identical, but the rebreathing unit was quite different (see details). The Navy Smoke Mask was most likely employed for rescue work where high levels of smoke filled confined spaces and oxygen levels were too low to sustain life. The Model NM seems to be more commonly found today on the surplus market when compared with the other Navy rebreathers, but it is nonetheless rare.

US Navy Oxygen Rescue Breathing Apparatus US Navy Oxygen Rescue Breathing Apparatus
Type A-3 (NORBA Type A-3) c. 1980s Rare United States Military (Navy) US-186 US-186 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-186.jpg $60 The NORBA Type A-3 was an updated version of the Navy's earlier rebreathers. The Type A-3 used a face piece based on the Navy Diaphragm Mark IV gas mask from WWII, and went on to be used well into the 1980s before it was replaced by a newer design. The Type A-3 is somewhat difficult to find today, as are most Navy rebreather units.

US Navy Oxygen Breathing Apparatus, Type B US Navy Oxygen Breathing Apparatus, Type B
n/a c. 1940s Rare/Scarce United States Military (Navy) US-193 US-193 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-193.jpg $225 The Navy Oxygen Breathing Apparatus Type B was a smaller rebreather unit that was most likely used for escape purposes. The unit came with a small half mask which was attached to the rebreather via a small corrugated hose. The mask also came equipped with a speech diaphragm identical to those used with all of the Navy masks from the WWII era. Also included was a pair of Willson safety goggles and several replacement canisters. The unit was stowed in a large wooden crate.

US Navy Oxygen Rebreathing Apparatus - US Navy Oxygen Rebreathing Apparatus -
Central Oxygen Supply Type c. 1942 Rare/Scarce United States Military (Navy) US-199 US-199 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-199.jpg $375 The Central Supply Type Oxygen Rebreathing Apparatus was designed to be used by aviators at high altitudes, by supplying them with rebreathable air containing a high percentage of oxygen. The unit could be hooked up to a central oxygen reservoir for prolonged use. The unit could be either carried or stowed near the wearer during use. These bulky rebreathers are quite rare today, but when found are typically in un-issued co nditio n.

US Army M2-10-6 Lightweight Optical Gas Mask US Army M2-10-6 Lightweight Optical Gas Mask
n/a c. 1944 Scarce United States Military (Army) US-191 US-191 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-191.jpg $675 The M2-10-6 was a new light-weight optical mask which took design elements from several earlier US Army masks. The optical eye pieces were identical to the Army MI-I-5 Optical Gas Mask, while the exhale valve/speech diaphragm assembly was identical to the M3A1 Diaphragm Gas Mask. Instead of carrying the filter canister behind the head (as with previous optical masks), the M2-10-6 used a M10 Filter canister attached to a long corrugated rubber hose, basically identical to the M3 and M4 series light-weight service masks. The M2-10-6 was most likely not manufactured in significant numbers, as this mask is quite scarce today. In the early 1950s, it was replaced by the more common M2-10A1-6 Lightweight Optical Gas Mask (see below).

US Army M2-10A1-6 Lightweight Optical Gas Mask US Army M2-10A1-6 Lightweight Optical Gas Mask
n/a c. 1952 Uncommon United States Military (Army) US-048 US-048 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-048.jpg $600 The M2-10A1-6 is perhaps one of the strangest looking US gas masks. The speech diaphragm was protected by a metal mesh-like material giving it a peculiar appearance. The M2-10A1-6 used the same adjustable eye pieces that were used on the earlier Army Optical Gas Masks and the N.D.O. Mark I. A lightweight M10A1 filter canister was attached to the mask via a corrugated rubber breathing tube. The mask's main purpose was to provide the Army with a gas mask that could be accurately used with optical sighting devices like scopes and binoculars. The M2-10A1-6 was manufactured in quantity, and it can be found fairly easily with a little searching, and often in mint un-issued condition.

US Navy Diaphragm (ND) Gas Mask, Mark V US Navy Diaphragm (ND) Gas Mask, Mark V
n/a c. 1957 Uncommon United States Military (Navy) US-049 US-049 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-049.jpg $60 The US Navy Mark V Gas Mask is interesting in that it is the only US gas mask to use this particular setup; the design is nothing like the earlier Navy diaphragm gas masks. The Mark V used a single plastic visor type eye piece, which offered an excellent field of view, but on the same token was prone to fogging as there was no inner mask installed. An adjustable five strap rubber head harness was used for suspension and two C1 filter discs were used for filtration. The speech diaphragm and exhale valve are clearly visible on the front of the mask. The Mark V came in a special gray fabric carrier that was reinforced with an angled piece of flat metal. The ND Mark V can be found readily on the surplus market in excellent condition.

US E15R3 Protective Mask Headpiece US E15R3 Protective Mask Headpiece
n/a c. 1950s/1960s Very Scarce United States Military US-204 US-204 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-204.jpg ? $300+ This experimental mask was most likely designed during the testing of various types of gas hoods for use during decontamination duty. The E15R3 consisted of a butyl hood which was incorporated with a half-mask and head harness on the inside. Two large circular eye pieces were also fitted directly to the hood. Unlike most protective mask hoods, this device was intended to be a standalone mask, rather than a hood that could be worn over a standard issue respirator. The E15R3 pictured here, is shown with a MSA Rocket Propellant filter canister.

US Army E48 Gas Mask US Army E48 Gas Mask
E19R25 (original M.I.T. designation) c. late 1940s Scarce United States Military (Army) US-050 US-050 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-050.jpg $490 After the failure of the M5 Assault Gas Mask, a new lightweight combat gas mask was in demand. The E48, later standardized as the M9 Field Protective Mask, was the basis for one of the most successful gas mask designs ever. For the most part, the E48 is identical to the standardized M9, however both the E48 and several early M9 gas masks were made from black rubber instead of the more common gray rubber used for the bulk of all M9 and M9A1 gas masks manufactured. Because the E48 was technically a prototype mask, it is not commonly found on the collector's market and is quite rare today in any condition.

US Army M9 Field Protective Gas Mask US Army M9 Field Protective Gas Mask
n/a c. 1950s Scarce United States Military (Army) US-051 US-051 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-051.jpg $385 The US Army M9 Field Protective Gas Mask is perhaps one of the most successful gas mask designs ever. It remained in use for approximately two decades and it has been copied by at least five countries. The M9 owes it's design to the earlier US E48 gas mask, which was an experimental upgrade based on the Army M5 Assault Gas Mask. The M9 pictured to the right is an early production example with a face piece made entirely from black rubber like the prototype E48 shown above. It is dated 1952. Aside from the use of black rubber, this M9 is identical to the standard gray rubber production model (see below).

US Army M9/M9A1 Field Protective Gas Mask US Army M9/M9A1 Field Protective Gas Mask
n/a c. 1951 Common United States Military/Civilian (Army/Police) US-052 US-052 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-052.jpg $40 The US Army M9 Field Protective Gas Mask is perhaps one of the most successful gas mask designs ever. It remained in use for approximately two decades and it has been copied by at least five countries. The only difference between the M9 and M9A1 are the carriers, the masks themselves are identical. The M9 design, was basically an upgraded version of the US M5-11-7 Assault Service Gas Mask. It used the same 60mm M11 drum type filter canister that was attached to the side of the mask. The M9 was most commonly manufactured with the filter inlet on the left side, however, a right side filer inlet version was also made. This was to accommodate left handed personnel during weapon sighting. Because the M9 was in service for so many years, it is now one of the most commonly found US gas masks on the surplus market.

US Army M9/M9A1 Field Protective Gas Mask (Right sided filter inlet) US Army M9/M9A1 Field Protective Gas Mask (Right sided filter inlet)
n/a c. 1951 Uncommon United States Military/Civilian (Army/Police) US-053 US-053 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-053.jpg $40 This version of the US Army M9 Field Protective mask is basically identical to the above version, but was manufactured with the filter inlet on the right side. This was to accommodate left-handed soldiers when sighting their rifles. M9s with the filter on the right side are slightly more difficult to find today as fewer were manufactured.

US Army M15 Compressed Air Breathing Apparatus US Army M15 Compressed Air Breathing Apparatus
n/a c . 1950s Scarce United States Military (Army) US-054 US-054 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-054.jpg $245 The M15 Compressed Air Breathing Apparatus used the M9 face piece with a corrugated rubber hose attached to the side instead of the standard M11 filter. The hose was connected to two compressed air tanks that allowed closed circuit breathing. The M15 setup was most likely used for emergency situations where the oxygen levels were too low to sustain life. The heavy air canisters were strapped to a harness that allowed the wearer to sling the apparatus around the back. The M15 Compressed Air Breathing Apparatus is quite rare today as few were most likely manufactured.

US Army ABC-M21 Rocket Propellant Gas Mask US Army ABC-M21 Rocket Propellant Gas Mask
n/a c. 1950s Very Scarce United States Military US-055 US-055 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-055.jpg ? $150+ Like the M15 Compressed Air Breathing Apparatus, the ABC-M21 Rocket Propellant Gas Mask also used a standard M9 face piece. The corrugated rubber hose attached to the side of the mask was connected to a large filter manufactured to protect against rocket fuel fumes. The heavy filter canister was carried inside a leather sling and was worn around the wearer's neck. This setup is also very scarce today as few were likely manufactured.

US MI-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask US MI-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask
n/a c. 1941 Rare/Scarce United States Civilian US-056 US-056 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-056.jpg $290 This version of the MI-I-I Noncombatant gas mask is certainly the most scarce, and it is most likely the earliest version manufactured. US MI-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask US MI-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask
n/a c. 1941 Rare/Scarce United States Civilian US-198 US-198 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-198.jpg $290 This MI-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask is very similar to the above version, and without a doubt, just as rare. US MI-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask US MI-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask
n/a c. 1941 Rare/Scarce United States Civilian US-057 US-057 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-057.jpg $190 Pictured to the right, is the more common of the two MI-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask versions. This one used a rubberized fabric face piece that was stitched together in the same manner as the previous version. While this version is more common that the above version, it is still quite scarce on the collector's market today. US MIA2-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask US MIA2-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask
n/a c. 1943 Common United States Civilian US-058 US-058 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-058.jpg $25 Perhaps the most commonly found US gas mask from the W.W.II era is the MIA2-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask. It is not difficult to find these masks still in the original cardboard box. The face piece was made of a thin piece of rubberized material that was more comfortable than the earlier MI-I-I. The chin area was shaped to accommodate the wearers chin and thus created a better fit. The MIV button type exhale valve was replaced with the widely used M8 exhale valve. The large fixed filter was secured in place with a metal band as opposed to a rubber band, making it more durable and less likely to leak.

US MIA2-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask (Child Size) US MIA2-I-I Noncombatant Gas Mask (Child Size)
n/a c. 1943 Common United States Civilian US-059 US-059 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-059.jpg $35 The only difference between this mask and the above mask is the size. This version was specially designed for young children, but all of the same components were used. Only the face piece itself was smaller. The MIA2-I-I (Child Size) is for the most part as easily found as the common adult size, but does require a bit more searching.

US M2-2-1 Noncombatant Gas Mask (Small Child) US M2-2-1 Noncombatant Gas Mask (Small Child)
n/a c. 1943 Uncommon United States Civilian US-060 US-060 https://dl.dropbox.com/u/14570796/Images/US-060.jpg $80 The M2-2-1 Small Child Noncombatant gas mask is certainly one of the tiniest gas masks ever made.
